title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("iancero/rollout", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: Please note rollout project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

code: @Manual{,   title = {rollout: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)},   author = {First Last},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://iancero.github.io/rollout/},   url = {https://github.com/iancero/rollout}, }

what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: rollout trial involves “rolling ” intervention across different sites groups incremental phases. rollout package simulates evaluates statistical properties (e.g., power) different rollout study designs.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Rollout development therefore yet available CRAN. However, can install development version rollout via GitHub.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: rollout package follows four-step workflow simulating evaluating rollout designs. Specifying rollout schedule expected intervention effects. Simulating several datasets. Fitting statistical model dataset. Evaluating statistical properties (e.g., power, bias) fitted models. Rollout’s functions designed guide steps, described detail .

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: step, specify rollout schedule expected effects conditions (e.g., interventions) schedule. example, might specify intervention rolled three phases, lasting different amount time.1 three month baseline phase, intervention applied, data participating cohort collected. two month intervention phase, cohort receives intervention. four month sustainment phase, intervention longer applied, data still collected evaluate whether effects intervention persist beyond initial application. Specifying rollout schedule rollout package done creating named list rollout phase durations. names list elements correspond names phases, values correspond duration phase time steps. example, rollout schedule described specified follows: Phase effects specified similar way. example, might specify intervention effect baseline phase, positive effect intervention phase, smaller positive effect sustainment phase.
code: library(rollout)  phase_durations <- list(baseline = 3, intervention = 2, sustainment = 4) phase_effects <- list(baseline = 0, intervention = 2, sustainment = 1)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: generate sample data, need phase durations phase effects, well general simulation parameters (e.g., sample size). example, might specify design rolled across 12 cohorts, 100 subjects. keep track growing collection parameters, ’ll combine specifications named list. Lastly, simulate several datasets consistent rollout schedule expected effects. simulate_rollout_samples() function generates dataset specified number cohorts subjects per cohort, adds columns phase, time, outcome variables.
code: cohorts <- 12 subjects_per_cohort <- 100 sim_params <- list(   phase_durations = phase_durations,   phase_effects = phase_effects,   cohorts = cohorts,   subjects_per_cohort = subjects_per_cohort) simulated_samples_df <- simulate_rollout_samples(sim_params, n = 10)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: collection simulated samples generated, fit_model() function can used fit linear mixed-effects model dataset. model includes fixed effects phase, time, cohort, random effects cohort subject.
code: model <- "y ~ phase + (1 | .cohort/.subject)"  fitted_models <- fit_model(simulated_samples_df, model) #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `.fit = purrr::map(data, ~lmerTest::lmer(model, data = .x))`. #> Caused by warning in `checkConv()`: #> ! Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.00215223 (tol = 0.002, component 1)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Finally, can evaluate statistical properties fitted models get sense quality rollout design. eval_design() function calculates range useful statistics, including power bias estimated intervention effect phase.
code: eval_design(fitted_models, feature = "power") #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   term              power #>   <chr>             <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept)           0 #> 2 phaseintervention     1 #> 3 phasesustainment      1

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: rollout package includes number advanced features help simulate evaluate rollout designs.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: rollout package designed pipe-friendly, can easily chain together multiple functions simulate evaluate rollout designs. entire workflow can written single pipe, like :

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Rollout trials typically involve multi-level effects large sample size. means simulations rollout trials can slow memory intensive. rollout package addresses issues proactively comes equipped range features speed computation.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: rollout package uses data.table package (via dtplyr) backend data manipulation. allows faster data processing efficient memory usage, especially simulations large samples.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: rollout package supports parallel processing, can significantly speed simulations large rollout trials. default, package uses future package run simulations parallel. can control number cores used parallel processing setting future::plan() options.
code: future::plan(future::multisession, workers = 4)  results <- sim_params |>    sim_samples(n = 100) |>    fit_models(model) |>    eval_design(feature = c("power", "bias"))

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Although final inferences based full set simulations, study design process typically iterative exploratory. rollout package supports “threshold inferences,” can speed simulations stopping simulation process early, given design statistic (e.g., power) crossed particilar threshold.
code: results <- sim_params |>    sim_samples(n = 100) |>    fit_models(model) |>    eval_design(     feature = c("power", "bias"),      threshold = list(power = 0.8, p = 0.05))

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: rollout package includes progress bar help track progress simulations. progress bar displayed default, can turned setting show_progress argument FALSE.

what: Add normally-distributed error to a dataset — sim_normal_error
title: Add normally-distributed error to a dataset — sim_normal_error
text: function adds column normally distributed error dataset designed simulation data rollout design.

title: Add normally-distributed error to a dataset — sim_normal_error
Add normally-distributed error to a dataset — sim_normal_error
text: .data dataframe simulated rollout data sd standard deviation error term

title: Add normally-distributed error to a dataset — sim_normal_error
text: original .data dataframe, new column called .error appended .

title: Add normally-distributed error to a dataset — sim_normal_error
text: function intended used simulation rollout-based dataset. error term normally distributed mean 0 standard deviation 1 (default).

title: Add normally-distributed error to a dataset — sim_normal_error
code: mtcars |>  sim_normal_error() #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘dplyr’  mtcars |>  sim_normal_error(sd = 2) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘dplyr’
